study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of taurine in modulating eryptosis (programmed erythrocyte death) and its potential implications in clinical conditions.
results_summary: The study found that taurine transporter (TAUT) deficiency in mice decreased eryptosis, suggesting taurine may play a protective role against premature erythrocyte death. This effect was observed alongside other genetic modifications influencing eryptosis.
population_specificity: Mice with deficient taurine transporter (TAUT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine could prevent methamphetamine-induced developmental angiogenesis defects and vascular malformation through antioxidant mechanisms.
results_summary: Taurine significantly increased in endothelial cells exposed to methamphetamine and effectively reversed methamphetamine-induced inhibition of cell proliferation and migration, reduced zebrafish embryo death rates and vessel abnormalities, and mitigated oxidative stress and apoptosis-related dysregulations.
population_specificity: Human embryo endothelial cells and zebrafish embryos exposed to methamphetamine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate taurine's effects on various models of renal dysfunction, including hypertension, proteinuria, glomerular/tubular disorders, and diabetic nephropathy, and explore its potential clinical significance.
results_summary: The review highlights studies showing taurine's potential benefits in addressing renal dysfunction, including acute/chronic conditions, urinary tract issues, and diabetic nephropathy, but does not provide specific quantitative outcomes.
population_specificity: Models of renal dysfunction (e.g., hypertension, proteinuria, glomerular/tubular disorders, diabetic nephropathy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between taurine conjugation patterns in bile acids and the effects of UDCA treatment in PBC patients and healthy controls.
results_summary: Taurine conjugates of chenodeoxycholic acid were more prominent in PBC patients' bile than in healthy controls, and UDCA treatment normalized biliary bile acid conjugation patterns. Taurine conjugation may serve as an adaptive mechanism against bile duct damage in PBC.
population_specificity: 11 PBC patients and 11 matched healthy subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss emerging acne treatments, including taurine bromamine, and evaluate their potential role in therapy.
results_summary: The abstract mentions taurine bromamine as an emerging adjunctive treatment for acne, but no specific results or outcomes related to its efficacy are detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general acne vulgaris patients implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral or transdermal glutathione supplementation could increase plasma taurine levels in children with ASD.
results_summary: Both oral and transdermal glutathione supplementation significantly increased plasma taurine levels in children with ASD. The study did not report adverse effects related to taurine specifically.
population_specificity: Children aged 3-13 years diagnosed with an autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
effective_dosage: Not specified for taurine (study focused on glutathione supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of hypolipidemic drugs on oxidative stress and plasma taurine levels in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: Taurine concentration significantly increased during therapy, particularly with ezetimibe/simvastatin 10/40 mg/day (+31.6%). Oxidative stress markers (MDA and All/UA ratio) decreased, and reduced forms of thiols increased, with improvements correlated to higher taurine levels.
population_specificity: 30 CKD patients
effective_dosage: Simvastatin (40 mg/day) or ezetimibe/simvastatin (10/20 or 10/40 mg/day)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify the roles of the blood-brain barrier (BBB) and blood-CSF barrier (BCSFB) in the transport of creatine and guanidinoacetate, including the involvement of the taurine transporter TauT.
results_summary: The study found that under physiological conditions, the taurine transporter TauT facilitates a net exit of guanidinoacetate from CSF to blood at the BCSFB, particularly in GAMT deficiency. No uptake of guanidinoacetate occurs at the BBB except in GAMT deficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on transport mechanisms and clinical evidence from AGAT-, GAMT-, and SLC6A8-deficient patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the neuroprotective effects of taurine-conjugated bile acids, particularly in relation to Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: The study found that taurine-conjugated ursodeoxycholic acid exhibits neuroprotective effects in vitro, suggesting potential relevance for Alzheimer's disease. The abstract highlights broader biological effects of bile acids, including anti-inflammatory and metabolic regulation.
population_specificity: In vitro (cell-based) study, not specified for human or animal models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of dietary cysteine and its derivatives, including taurine, in enhancing antioxidant status and improving outcomes in certain diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights that taurine, as part of sulfur amino acid metabolism, plays a key role in antioxidant pathways and may help combat chronic inflammation by supporting glutathione synthesis. Critically ill patients showed improved glutathione synthesis when cysteine metabolism was optimized.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients and general discussion of sulfur amino acid metabolism in stressed and inflammatory states.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review evidence on taurine's beneficial effects in diabetes and its complications, particularly cardiovascular health, to support future clinical and epidemiological studies on taurine supplementation.
results_summary: The review found sufficient evidence from experimental, in vitro, and some clinical studies to support taurine's potential in preventing and treating diabetes complications, primarily through antioxidant and anti-inflammatory mechanisms.
population_specificity: Diabetes patients and associated cardiovascular complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine mediates relaxation in gastric clasp and sling muscle fibers, potentially influencing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD).
results_summary: The study found that taurine did not relax bethanechol-precontracted gastric clasp or sling fibers, indicating no direct role in the relaxation mechanisms examined.
population_specificity: Muscle strips from organ donors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the SLCO1B1 polymorphism affects the pharmacokinetics of UDCA and its taurine conjugates in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of the SLCO1B1 genotype on the pharmacokinetics of UDCA or its taurine conjugates. UDCA ingestion increased plasma concentrations of certain endogenous bile acids but did not impact taurine conjugate levels.
population_specificity: Healthy volunteers with specific SLCO1B1 genotypes (*1A/*1A, *1B/*1B, *15/*15, or *5/*15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a proprietary blend containing taurine (STPG capsule) could improve exercise performance and energy substrate utilization in humans.
results_summary: The study found that STPG supplementation significantly increased exercise time to exhaustion, reduced plasma lactate concentrations during exercise, and enhanced free fatty acid utilization compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 14 male volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of taurine supplementation on exercise capacity in patients with heart failure.
results_summary: Taurine supplementation significantly increased exercise time, metabolic equivalents (METS), and exercise distance in heart failure patients after 2 weeks, while placebo showed no significant improvement.
population_specificity: 29 patients with heart failure (LVEF <50%, NYHA class II or III), mostly male (26 of 29), mean age 60.57 ± 6.54 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical efficacy of altered doses of taurine supplementation in parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: The abstract notes that little data is available on the clinical efficacy of taurine supplementation in parenteral nutrition, indicating a lack of rigorous studies to support its use. No specific findings on taurine's effects are reported.
population_specificity: Adult and pediatric patients requiring parenteral nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine could contribute to the prevention of heart disease, focusing on its antioxidant properties and effects on cardiovascular health.
results_summary: Taurine was shown to positively impact coronary artery disease, blood pressure, plasma cholesterol, and myocardial function in animal models, with a notable role as an antioxidant by absorbing hypochlorous acid. However, its beneficial effects in antioxidant therapy were noted as underpromoted.
population_specificity: Animal models of human disease (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers examined the potential association between taurine deficiency and vigabatrin-associated retinal toxicity, as well as taurine's role in preventing this retinopathy.
results_summary: The study suggests an association between vigabatrin-associated retinal toxicity and taurine deficiency, indicating taurine may play a preventive role in this retinopathy. However, the evidence is based on reviewed data rather than direct experimental results.
population_specificity: Patients with epilepsy, including those treated with vigabatrin or other GABAergic antiepileptic therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and therapeutic potential of taurine bromamine (TauBr), particularly in treating acne vulgaris.
results_summary: TauBr demonstrated strong anti-inflammatory and antimicrobial properties, effectively killing Propionibacterium acnes and reducing acne lesions comparably to clindamycin in a double-blind trial. It also induced heme oxygenase-1 (HO-1), enhancing its anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate inflammatory facial acne vulgaris.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential role of taurine in the treatment of diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN), focusing on its mechanisms and therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The abstract mentions taurine as part of the search terms but does not provide specific findings on its effects for DPN. It highlights oxidative/nitrosative stress as a key pathogenic factor, which taurine may target.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic neuropathy, particularly diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine (TAU) could inhibit PARP activity and attenuate diabetes-related biochemical alterations in a streptozotocin-induced diabetic rat model.
results_summary: Taurine demonstrated PARP inhibitory activity, though less potent than 3-AB and NIC, and significantly reversed diabetes-induced metabolic disturbances, with dose-related effects observed at ≥2.4 mM/kg. Its protective effects were comparable to NIC but required higher doses to match the efficacy of stronger PARP inhibitors like 3-AB.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with streptozotocin-induced type 2 diabetes.
effective_dosage: 1.2 mM/kg, 2.4 mM/kg, and 3.6 mM/kg (single intraperitoneal dose).
study_duration: Acute intervention (blood samples collected 24 hours post-STZ administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of taurine as a treatment for systemic sclerosis (SSc) by examining its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antifibrotic properties.
results_summary: Taurine was found to inhibit proinflammatory cytokines (IL-1, IL-6) and TGF-beta, a fibrogenic cytokine, suggesting it may mitigate endothelial damage and fibrosis in SSc. The study concludes that taurine could be a novel therapeutic option for SSc.
population_specificity: Systemic sclerosis (SSc) patients (specific demographic details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of taurolidine on reducing inflammation and arrhythmias in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG).
results_summary: Taurolidine significantly decreased serum IL-6 and increased IL-10 in crystalloid cardioplegia patients, along with reducing ischemia/reperfusion-induced arrhythmias. Similar trends were observed in blood cardioplegia patients, though not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 60 patients undergoing CABG, divided into four groups based on cardioplegia type and treatment (placebo or taurolidine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review taurolidine's mechanisms and potential role in cancer treatment, focusing on its antineoplastic activity.
results_summary: Taurolidine induces cancer cell death through multiple mechanisms, including apoptosis, angiogenesis inhibition, and immune regulation, with supportive in vitro and animal data. Clinical studies are limited, but taurolidine appears nontoxic and is being evaluated in ongoing trials.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review, includes in vitro, animal, and limited clinical data).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify whether taurine, among other amino acids, could be a potential candidate for modulating intestinal inflammation in inflammatory bowel diseases (IBDs).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings on taurine's effects, only suggesting that it should be evaluated in future studies.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBDs), particularly Crohn's disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interaction between taurine availability and neridronate treatment in thalassemia major-induced osteoporosis, and to assess changes in bone mineral content and vertebral projection area.
results_summary: The study found a significant decrease in plasma taurine levels and urinary excretion after 12 months of neridronate treatment, alongside a significant increase in bone mineral content and vertebral projection area. These results suggest a potential interaction between neridronate and taurine metabolism, warranting further research on taurine supplementation.
population_specificity: Twelve patients (5 males, 7 females) aged 20-29 years with thalassemia major-induced osteoporosis following a hypertransfusion protocol.
effective_dosage: Neridronate infusion (30 mg in 100 ml saline) administered monthly.
interactions: Possible interaction between neridronate and taurine availability was suggested.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of taurine-conjugated bile acids in intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy and assess the effects of ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) treatment on these bile acids.
results_summary: The study found that intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy was associated with increased taurine-conjugated bile acids, particularly taurocholic and taurodeoxycholic acids, which were significantly reduced by UDCA treatment. Bile acid profiles in normal pregnancy and pruritus gravidarum were similar, distinguishing the latter from intrahepatic cholestasis.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy (n=63), normal pregnant women (n=26), and women with pruritus gravidarum (n=43).
effective_dosage: Not specified for taurine; UDCA treatment duration was ≥21 days.
study_duration: From 16 weeks of gestation to 4 weeks postpartum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether L-theanine from tea (Camellia sinensis) could mitigate doxorubicin-induced ovarian endoplasmic reticulum stress in rats.
results_summary: Both doses of L-theanine (200 and 400 mg/kg) effectively reversed doxorubicin-induced endoplasmic reticulum stress by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and apoptosis, with the higher dose showing more significant effects. L-theanine also alleviated morphological changes in ovarian tissues.
population_specificity: Female rats treated with doxorubicin.
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg and 400 mg/kg L-theanine, administered via oral gavage for three consecutive days.
study_duration: Three days (following a single doxorubicin dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize the pathogen causing tea gray blight disease in Camellia sinensis and confirm its pathogenicity.
results_summary: The study identified Neopestalotiopsis chrysea as the causative agent of tea gray blight, confirmed its pathogenicity through Koch's postulates, and provided molecular and morphological characterization. The disease incidence was highest in 'Baiye No. 1' tea plants, with symptoms including yellow-green lesions progressing to brown spots with concentric rings.
population_specificity: Tea plants (Camellia sinensis) in a 300 ha plantation in Jiangsu province, China, particularly the 'Baiye No. 1' cultivar.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of CsPAT1 in enhancing drought tolerance in tea plants by regulating the phenylpropanoid metabolic pathway.
results_summary: The study found that CsPAT1 transgenic Arabidopsis lines exhibited enhanced drought tolerance, increased antioxidant enzyme activities, higher proline content, and elevated levels of specific flavonoid compounds, suggesting CsPAT1's role in drought resistance via phenylpropanoid pathway regulation.
population_specificity: Transgenic Arabidopsis lines (model organism for studying tea plant mechanisms).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Bacillus mucilaginosus could enhance the recovery of tea plants (Camellia sinensis) from low-temperature stress by altering endophytic bacterial communities and improving physiological responses.
results_summary: The study found that B. mucilaginosus increased endophytic bacterial diversity, boosted antioxidant enzyme activity, and improved photosynthetic recovery in tea plants after low-temperature stress, enhancing their resistance and recovery.
population_specificity: Tea plants (Camellia sinensis) exposed to low-temperature stress.
effective_dosage: Different concentrations of B. mucilaginosus (T1, T2, T3), exact amounts not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the absorption, distribution, and metabolism of glyphosate, bentazone, and atrazine in hydroponic tea seedlings under single and mixed herbicide treatments.
results_summary: Mixed herbicide treatments led to greater accumulation of precursors and metabolites, higher residue levels, and more severe phytotoxic effects compared to single treatments, including reduced chlorophyll content and increased malondialdehyde levels. Herbicide distribution varied by compound, with metabolites showing significant accumulation under mixed treatments.
population_specificity: Hydroponic tea seedlings (Camellia sinensis).
effective_dosage: 20, 50, and 100 mg L-1 of glyphosate, bentazone, and atrazine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how epigallocatechin-3-gallate (EGCG) affects Agrobacterium transformation efficiency to optimize genetic modification in tea plants.
results_summary: The study found that EGCG at 0.4 mg/mL significantly reduced Agrobacterium transformation efficiency in tobacco, increased malondialdehyde content, and down-regulated genes involved in flagellar synthesis and secretion systems. Key genes (flgE, virB4, virB6) were identified as critical under EGCG stress.
population_specificity: Tobacco (used as a model for tea plants)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of L-theanine from tea in preventing DNCB-induced atopic dermatitis in BALB/c mice.
results_summary: L-theanine treatment mitigated DNCB-induced increases in leukocytes and macrophages, showed no cytotoxicity, and bound more effectively to filaggrin than DNCB, suggesting potential as an ameliorative agent for atopic dermatitis.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine supplementation reverses early endothelial abnormalities in young male type 1 diabetics.
results_summary: Taurine supplementation for 2 weeks restored arterial stiffness and brachial artery reactivity to control levels in young male type 1 diabetics, indicating a reversal of early vascular abnormalities. The study suggests taurine may have long-term benefits in preventing atherosclerotic disease progression in diabetics.
population_specificity: Young, asymptomatic male type 1 diabetics (n=9) and healthy controls (n=10).
effective_dosage: Not specified (only mentioned as "taurine" without dosage details).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antiviral effects of natural plant extracts, including Tea (Camellia sinensis), against influenza A virus (IAV).
results_summary: The study found that Tea (Camellia sinensis) was effective in preventing the entry or binding of IAV into host cells, suggesting potential antiviral properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or animal studies implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of salicylic acid (SA) and its derivatives, particularly the glycosyltransferase CsUGT74B5, in tea plant immunity and resistance to anthracnose.
results_summary: The study found that CsUGT74B5 glycosylates SA and 2,6-DHBA, reducing free SA levels and increasing SA 2-O-β-D-glucoside (SAG), which heightened tea plant sensitivity to anthracnose. Overexpression of CsUGT74B5 in tea plants and model organisms confirmed its role in modulating SA levels and disease resistance.
population_specificity: Tea seedlings (Camellia sinensis) and model organisms (Arabidopsis thaliana and Nicotiana tabacum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of theabrownin (TB) from Fu brick tea on glucose homeostasis, lipid metabolism, and inflammation in obese/diabetic mice.
results_summary: TB significantly reduced fasting blood glucose, insulin resistance, and inflammation while improving intestinal integrity and altering gut metabolites, particularly l-palmitoylcarnitine, which mediated metabolic improvements via the circadian gene Per3.
population_specificity: Obese/diabetic KKAy mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a polyherbal anti-acne facewash gel containing Tea (Camellia sinensis) extract in treating acne.
results_summary: The study found that the formulation containing Tea (Camellia sinensis) demonstrated excellent spreading coefficient, good physical appearance, and non-irritating properties, with formulation F3 showing superior efficacy compared to commercial products.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely individuals with acne, but exact demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: 0.80% concentration in formulation F3 (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the pathogen responsible for brown leaf spot disease in Duyun Maojian Tea and confirm its pathogenicity.
results_summary: The study identified Diaporthe pescicola as the causative pathogen of leaf spot in Duyun Maojian Tea, confirmed through morphological and molecular analysis, and fulfilled Koch's postulates. This is the first report of D. pescicola causing leaf spot in tea plants globally.
population_specificity: Duyun Maojian Tea plants in an experimental field in Qiannan Normal University for Nationalities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial and antibiofilm activities of Camellia sinensis (green tea) extract against Staphylococcus aureus strains, including MRSA.
results_summary: The study found that Camellia sinensis exhibited strong antibacterial activity, with MIC values ranging from 0.2 to 12.4 mg/mL, and contributed to inhibiting biofilm growth by 80-85% after 24 hours of incubation.
population_specificity: Staphylococcus aureus strains from ATCC collections and clinical isolates.
effective_dosage: Not specified (MIC values ranged from 0.2 to 12.4 mg/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of soil pH and cadmium (Cd) concentrations on tea plant growth physiology and identify key genes involved in Cd²⁺ transport.
results_summary: The study found that lower soil pH and higher Cd concentrations negatively affected tea plant growth, photosynthesis, and antioxidant enzyme activity, while identifying CsHMA2 as a key gene influencing Cd²⁺ transport.
population_specificity: Tea plants (Camellia sinensis L. cultivar 'Longjing 43') grown under controlled pH and Cd conditions.
effective_dosage: Cd concentrations: T1 = 0 mg L⁻¹, T2 = 0.01 mg L⁻¹, T3 = 0.05 mg L⁻¹, T4 = 0.2 mg L⁻¹.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the molecular mechanism by which gibberellin regulates theanine synthesis in tea plants (Camellia sinensis).
results_summary: The study found that gibberellin promotes the expression of the theanine synthesis gene CsTSI and identified CsWRKY71 as a transcription factor mediating this regulation. Exogenous gibberellin alleviated CsWRKY71's inhibition of CsTSI, enhancing theanine biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Tea plants (Camellia sinensis)

study_goal: To determine the effects of oral vitamin A supplementation on clinical outcomes, particularly respiratory outcomes, in preterm infants.
results_summary: Oral vitamin A supplementation did not significantly affect mechanical ventilation duration, oxygen requirement at 36 weeks PMA, or moderate-to-severe BPD, but slightly reduced noninvasive ventilation duration without adverse drug-related events.
population_specificity: Preterm infants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the physiological roles of Vitamin A, particularly its involvement in visual phototransduction.
results_summary: The study highlights Vitamin A's critical role in visual phototransduction, where it functions as a key component of photopigments, converting light into electrical signals. It also notes that both hyper- and hypovitaminosis of Vitamin A can be harmful.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate micronutrient retention, organoleptic properties, and acceptability of fortified rice, including Vitamin A.
results_summary: Retention rates of Vitamin A in multiple-micronutrient-fortified rice were variable, and cooking in excess water increased micronutrient loss. The study found challenges regarding the effect of Vitamin A-fortified rice on Vitamin A status.
population_specificity: Not specified (studies included any study populations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current knowledge on carotenoids, including Vitamin A, for their potential role in preventing and treating benign urological conditions.
results_summary: Vitamin A intake was associated with reduced urinary tract reinfection rates and decreased urolithiasis formation in rat models, though effects were moderate.
population_specificity: Patients with benign urological conditions (BPH, chronic prostatitis, urolithiasis, recurrent UTIs) and rat models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how malaria infection affects biomarkers of vitamin A status and whether adjustments for malaria are necessary in assessing micronutrient status.
results_summary: The study found that retinol concentrations were reduced in individuals with asymptomatic and clinical malaria, suggesting that malaria infection negatively impacts vitamin A status. The results were stable in sensitivity analyses, indicating a need to adjust for malaria when assessing vitamin A biomarkers.
population_specificity: Children and adults with asymptomatic or clinical malaria, and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Vitamin A, at concentrations above RDA levels but below toxicity limits, can reduce epithelial barrier leak and improve disease outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that Vitamin A, along with zinc and Vitamin D, can induce molecular-level changes in tight junctional complexes to reduce barrier leak, potentially lowering disease morbidity. The effects were observed across cell culture, animal, and human tissue models.
population_specificity: Not specified (review covers cell culture, animal, and human tissue models).
effective_dosage: Above RDA levels but below toxicity limits (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The study aimed to assess the impact of a poultry value chain intervention (SELEVER) on the probability of adequacy of vitamin A intake among women and children during the lean season.
results_summary: The study found no significant impact on the probability of adequacy of vitamin A intakes in women or children, despite increased egg consumption in children. Negative effects on zinc intake in women were observed relative to the SELEVER + WASH group.
population_specificity: Women and index children (2-4 years old) in 1054 households in rural settings.
study_duration: Two years (two survey rounds conducted 2 years apart)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of scaling up Vitamin A Supplementation (VAS) in reducing mortality associated with measles and diarrheal diseases among children in sub-Saharan Africa.
results_summary: The study found that scaling up VAS led to modest DALYs averted, with cost-effectiveness varying by country (Nigeria: $860/DALY, Kenya: $550/DALY, Burkina Faso: $220/DALY). The authors concluded that VAS may no longer be as cost-effective as previously thought due to updated disease burden estimates and competing interventions.
population_specificity: Children aged 6-59 months in Nigeria, Kenya, and Burkina Faso.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of Vitamin A supplementation in the supportive management of measles, particularly in reducing complications and improving patient outcomes.
results_summary: The study mentions Vitamin A supplementation as part of supportive therapy for measles, implying its use may help mitigate complications, though specific efficacy data or outcomes are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with measles, particularly children in resource-poor settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify therapeutic options for Darier's disease, including the effectiveness of systemic Vitamin A.
results_summary: The study identified Grade B evidence supporting the use of systemic Vitamin A for treating Darier's disease, indicating moderate efficacy. Other treatments, including retinoids and vitamin D analogs, were also reviewed.
population_specificity: Patients with Darier's disease (keratosis follicularis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enteral nutrition (EN) met the recommended dietary intake for Vitamin A and other micronutrients in mechanically ventilated ICU patients.
results_summary: The study found that EN delivery met the recommended dietary intake for Vitamin A when approximately 50% energy adequacy was achieved, but did not exceed the upper level of intake.
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated ICU patients in Melbourne, Australia (62 ± 16 years, 67% male).
study_duration: First 7 days of ICU admission (EN delivered for 5 [4-6] days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the role of micronutrient deficiencies, particularly fat-soluble vitamins like Vitamin A, in pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB) and their potential impact on epigenetic changes affecting drug-metabolizing pathways.
results_summary: The study suggests that Vitamin A deficiency may influence epigenetic changes in hepatic drug metabolic pathways, potentially affecting the pharmacokinetic variability of anti-TB drugs, but specific outcomes regarding Vitamin A's efficacy are not detailed.
population_specificity: Individuals with pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB) caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability and effectiveness of fat-soluble vitamins, including Vitamin A, delivered via liposomes or cyclodextrins versus medium-chain triglycerides in pancreatic-insufficient cystic fibrosis patients.
results_summary: The study measured changes in all-trans-retinol concentrations as a primary outcome, but specific results regarding Vitamin A's efficacy were not detailed in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: Pancreatic-insufficient cystic fibrosis patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the role of Vitamin A as a nutrient affecting the risk of developing ALS and the progression rate of motor neuron degeneration.
results_summary: The review indicated that Vitamin A was among the least significant protectors against ALS development, ranking lower than vitamins B12, E, C, and others. Its role was less understood or disputed compared to other nutrients.
population_specificity: ALS patients and animal models of ALS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral vitamin A supplementation (VAS) reduces the risk of acute respiratory tract infections (ARTI) in children and explored its effects in specific subgroups.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between VAS and reduced ARTI incidence compared to placebo. Higher-than-recommended VAS doses increased ARTI incidence by 13%, and well-nourished children in the high-dose group saw a 66% increase in ARTI incidence.
population_specificity: Children living in poor conditions, with subgroup analyses on well-nourished children.
effective_dosage: Higher than WHO recommendations (specific dosage not stated).

study_goal: The researchers compared the effects of standard and distal Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) on nutritional outcomes, including Vitamin A levels, in patients with a BMI of 50-60 kg/m².
results_summary: Vitamin A levels were lower after distal RYGB compared to standard RYGB, indicating a potential negative impact on Vitamin A status in this surgical context. No other significant effects on Vitamin A were reported.
population_specificity: Patients aged 18-60 years with a BMI of 50-60 kg/m² undergoing RYGB surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the intake of micronutrients, including Vitamin A, from enteral nutrition in critically ill patients with recommended dietary intakes and upper intake levels.
results_summary: The study found that enteral nutrition frequently met the recommended dietary intakes for Vitamin A and did not exceed upper intake levels. Acute Physiology and Chronic Health Evaluation scores ≥20 delivered a higher % of the recommended dietary intake of Vitamin A.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients receiving enteral nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the roles of hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) in vitamin A storage and their involvement in liver fibrosis.
results_summary: The study found that HSCs are the major vitamin A-storing cells in the liver, playing key roles in liver development and regeneration. Upon liver injury, activated HSCs contribute to fibrosis progression, while inactivated HSCs aid in fibrosis regression.
population_specificity: Hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) in the liver (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of the Swank and Wahls diets on micronutrient intake, including Vitamin A, in people with relapsing-remitting MS.
results_summary: The Wahls diet group showed significant reductions in inadequate Vitamin A intake from food at 12 weeks, indicating improved dietary adequacy. No adverse effects or toxicity related to Vitamin A were reported.
population_specificity: People with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (MS)
